\lecture{13}{2023-03-16}{}

 \subsection{Linear Planer Embeddings}
 \begin{note}
    Our definition of planer does not require straight lines
 \end{note}

\begin{question}
    \(G\) is planar \(\implies\) it can be drawn using straight lines
\end{question}

\begin{definition}[linear embedding]
    \label{def:linear embedding}
    An embedding drawn with only straight lines
\end{definition}

\begin{theorem}[Fary]
    \label{thm:fary}
    Every planar graph has a linear embedding    
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    By induction:
    \begin{enumerate}[align=left]
        \item[\emph{Base Case:}] (\(|V| =\))
    
        
        \item[\emph{Inductive Step:}]  
    
        
    \end{enumerate} 
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}
    A planar graph has at least four vertices of degree \(\leq 5\).
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose the degree of all the vertices are \(\geq 6\) then \(2|E| = \sum \deg(v) \geq 6|V|\)  but this contradicts \(|E| \leq 3|V| - 6\) 
\end{proof}


\subsection{Maximal Planar Graphs}
\begin{observe}
    For Fary's theorem adding edges makes it harder to linearly embedded
\end{observe}


\begin{definition}[maximal planar]
    \label{def:maximal planar}
    \(G\) is maximal planar if adding any edge to \(G\) gives a nonplanar graph
\end{definition}  

\begin{proposition}[max planar properties]
    \label{prop:max planar properties}
    Fix \(G = (V, E)\)
    The following are equivalent:
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item \(G\) is maximal planar
        \item \(|E| = 3|V| - 6\) 
        \item Complementary regions of \(G \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2\) is a triangle 
    \end{enumerate} 
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}[align=left]
        \item[]
        \item[\(2 \iff 3\)]:
        We saw that \(3|F| \leq |E|\) and with Euler we can see that \(|E| \leq 3|V| - 6\). We have equality of the second statement when the first statement has equality. Therefore, all the faces are triangles if and only if \(|E| \leq 3|V| - 6\).
        \item[\(1 \implies 3\)]:
        \(G \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2\) where some region has \(\geq 4\) sides. Then since we can add an edge in this case (ex. diagonal across square).
        \item[\(3 \implies 1\)]:
        \(G\) is not max planer then we can add edge \(e\) s.t. \(G^\prime = G \cup e\) is a;so planar. Then we have an embedding \(G^\prime \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2\) where we can remove \(e\) and see that we get an embedding of \(G\) with a region that's not a triangle.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\begin{example}[complementary region as traingles]
    \label{ex:complementary region as traingles}
% https://q.uiver.app/?
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	& \bullet &&&& \bullet \\
	\\
	\bullet && \bullet && \bullet && \bullet \\
	\bullet && \bullet && \bullet && \bullet
	\arrow[no head, from=1-2, to=3-1]
	\arrow[no head, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow[no head, from=4-1, to=4-3]
	\arrow[no head, from=4-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[no head, from=3-3, to=1-2]
	\arrow[no head, from=1-6, to=3-5]
	\arrow[no head, from=3-5, to=4-5]
	\arrow[no head, from=4-5, to=4-7]
	\arrow[no head, from=4-7, to=3-7]
	\arrow[no head, from=3-7, to=1-6]
	\arrow[no head, from=4-5, to=3-7]
	\arrow[curve={height=-30pt}, no head, from=1-6, to=4-7]
	\arrow[no head, from=3-5, to=3-7]
	\arrow[curve={height=30pt}, no head, from=1-6, to=4-5]
\end{tikzcd}\]
    Here the left graph is not maximal planar and does not have all triangle complementary regions (basically faces) while the right one does, including the outer region
\end{example}
